poem_title: BAUCIS AND PHILEMON. Imitated, From the Eighth Book of OVID.
author: Jonathan Swift
poem_alt_title: Imitated , From the Eighth Book of OVID .

lines.line_text: In antient Times, as Story tells,
The Saints would often leave their Cells.
And strole about, but hide their Quality,
To try good People's Hospitality.

stanzas.stanza_text:
In antient Times, as Story tells,
The Saints would often leave their Cells.
And strole about, but hide their Quality,
To try good People's Hospitality.

lines.line_text: IT happen'd on a Winter Night,
As Authors of the Legend write;
Two Brother Hermits, Saints by Trade,
Taking their  in Masquerade;
Disguis'd in tatter'd Habits, went
To a small Village down in ;
Where, in the Strolers Canting Strain,
They beg'd from Door to Door in vain;
Try'd ev'ry Tone might Pity win,
But not a Soul would let them in.
OUR wand'ring Saints in woful State,
Treated at this ungodly Rate,
Having thro' all the Village pass'd,
To a small Cottage came at last;
Where dwelt a good old honest Yeoman,
Call'd, in the Neighbourhood, .
Who kindly did the Saints invite
In his Poor Hut to pass the Night;
And then the Hospitable Sire
Bid   mend the Fire;
While He from out of Chimney took
A Flitch of Bacon off the Hook;
And freely from the fattest Side
Cut out large Slices to be fry'd;
Then stept aside to fetch 'em Drink,
Fill'd a large Jug up to the Brink;
And saw it fairly twice go round;
Yet (what is wonderful) they found,
'Twas still replenished to the Top,
As if they ne'er had toucht a Drop,
The good old Couple was amaz'd,
And often on each other gaz'd;
For both were frighted to the Heart,
And just began to cry; â€” What ar't
Then softly turn'd aside to view,
Whether the Lights were burning blue.
The gentle  soon aware on't,
Told 'em their Calling, and their Errant:
Good Folks, you need not be afraid,
We are but , the Hermits said;
No Hurt shall come to You, or Yours;
But, for that Pack of churlish Boors,
Not fit to live on Christian Ground,
They and their Houses shall be drown'd:
Whilst you shall see your Cottage rise,
And grow a Church before your Eyes.

stanzas.stanza_text:
OUR wand'ring Saints in woful State,
Treated at this ungodly Rate,
Having thro' all the Village pass'd,
To a small Cottage came at last;
Where dwelt a good old honest Yeoman,
Call'd, in the Neighbourhood, .
Who kindly did the Saints invite
In his Poor Hut to pass the Night;
And then the Hospitable Sire
Bid   mend the Fire;
While He from out of Chimney took
A Flitch of Bacon off the Hook;
And freely from the fattest Side
Cut out large Slices to be fry'd;
Then stept aside to fetch 'em Drink,
Fill'd a large Jug up to the Brink;
And saw it fairly twice go round;
Yet (what is wonderful) they found,
'Twas still replenished to the Top,
As if they ne'er had toucht a Drop,
The good old Couple was amaz'd,
And often on each other gaz'd;
For both were frighted to the Heart,
And just began to cry; â€” What ar't
Then softly turn'd aside to view,
Whether the Lights were burning blue.
The gentle  soon aware on't,
Told 'em their Calling, and their Errant:
Good Folks, you need not be afraid,
We are but , the Hermits said;
No Hurt shall come to You, or Yours;
But, for that Pack of churlish Boors,
Not fit to live on Christian Ground,
They and their Houses shall be drown'd:
Whilst you shall see your Cottage rise,
And grow a Church before your Eyes.

lines.line_text: THEY scarce had Spoke; when, fair and soft,
The Roof began to mount aloft;
Aloft rose ev'ry Beam and Rafter,
The heavy Wall climb'd slowly after

stanzas.stanza_text:
THEY scarce had Spoke; when, fair and soft,
The Roof began to mount aloft;
Aloft rose ev'ry Beam and Rafter,
The heavy Wall climb'd slowly after

lines.line_text: THE Chimney widen'd, and grew higher,
Became a Steeple with a Spire.

stanzas.stanza_text:
THE Chimney widen'd, and grew higher,
Became a Steeple with a Spire.

lines.line_text: THE Kettle to the Top was hoist,
And there stood fast'ned to a Joist:
But with the Upside down, to shew
Its Inclinations for below;
In vain; for a Superior Force
Apply'd at Bottom, stops its Course,
Doom'd ever in Suspence to dwell,
'Tis now no Kettle, but a Bell.

stanzas.stanza_text:
THE Kettle to the Top was hoist,
And there stood fast'ned to a Joist:
But with the Upside down, to shew
Its Inclinations for below;
In vain; for a Superior Force
Apply'd at Bottom, stops its Course,
Doom'd ever in Suspence to dwell,
'Tis now no Kettle, but a Bell.

lines.line_text: A wooden Jack, which had almost
Lost, by Disuse, the Art to Roast,
A sudden Alteration feels,
Increas'd by new Intestine Wheels:
And, what exalts the Wonder more,
The Number made the Motion slow'r:
The Flyer, tho't had Leaden Feet,
Turn'd round so quick, you scarce cou'd see't;
But slacken'd by some secret Power,
Now hardly moves an Inch an Hour.
The Jack and Chimney near ally'd,
Had never left each other's Side;
The Chimney to a Steeple grown,
The Jack wou'd not be left alone,
But up against the Steeple rear'd,
Became a Clock, and still adher'd:
And still its Love to Houshold Cares
By a shrill Voice at Noon declares,
Warning the Cook-maid, not to burn
That Roast-meat which it cannot turn.

stanzas.stanza_text:
A wooden Jack, which had almost
Lost, by Disuse, the Art to Roast,
A sudden Alteration feels,
Increas'd by new Intestine Wheels:
And, what exalts the Wonder more,
The Number made the Motion slow'r:
The Flyer, tho't had Leaden Feet,
Turn'd round so quick, you scarce cou'd see't;
But slacken'd by some secret Power,
Now hardly moves an Inch an Hour.
The Jack and Chimney near ally'd,
Had never left each other's Side;
The Chimney to a Steeple grown,
The Jack wou'd not be left alone,
But up against the Steeple rear'd,
Became a Clock, and still adher'd:
And still its Love to Houshold Cares
By a shrill Voice at Noon declares,
Warning the Cook-maid, not to burn
That Roast-meat which it cannot turn.

lines.line_text: THE Groaning Chair began to crawl
Like an huge Snail along the Wall;
There stuck aloft, in Publick View,
And with small Change, a Pulpit grew.

stanzas.stanza_text:
THE Groaning Chair began to crawl
Like an huge Snail along the Wall;
There stuck aloft, in Publick View,
And with small Change, a Pulpit grew.

lines.line_text: THE Porringers, that in a Row
Hung high, and made a glitt'ring Show,
To a less Noble Substance chang'd
Were now but Leathern Buckets rang'd.

stanzas.stanza_text:
THE Porringers, that in a Row
Hung high, and made a glitt'ring Show,
To a less Noble Substance chang'd
Were now but Leathern Buckets rang'd.

lines.line_text: THE Ballads pasted on the Wall,
Of  of , and ,
Fair , and ,
The :
Now seem'd to look abundance better,
Improv'd in Picture, Size, and Letter;
And high in Order plac'd describe
The Heraldry of ev'ry Tribe.

stanzas.stanza_text:
THE Ballads pasted on the Wall,
Of  of , and ,
Fair , and ,
The :
Now seem'd to look abundance better,
Improv'd in Picture, Size, and Letter;
And high in Order plac'd describe
The Heraldry of ev'ry Tribe.

lines.line_text: A Bedstead of the Antique Mode,
Compact of Timber many a Load,
Such as our Ancestors did use,
Was Metamorphos'd into Pews;
Which still their antient Nature keep;
By lodging Folks dispos'd to Sleep.
THE Cottage by such Feats as these,
Grown to a Church by just Degrees,
The Hermits then desir'd their Host
To ask for what he fancy'd most:
, having paus'd a while,
Return'd 'em Thanks in homely Stile;
Then said; my House is grown so Fine,
Methinks, I still wou'd call it mine:
I'm Old, and fain wou'd live at Ease,
Make me the , if you please.

stanzas.stanza_text:
THE Cottage by such Feats as these,
Grown to a Church by just Degrees,
The Hermits then desir'd their Host
To ask for what he fancy'd most:
, having paus'd a while,
Return'd 'em Thanks in homely Stile;
Then said; my House is grown so Fine,
Methinks, I still wou'd call it mine:
I'm Old, and fain wou'd live at Ease,
Make me the , if you please.

lines.line_text: HE spoke, and presently he feels,
His Grazier's Coat fall down his Heels;
He sees, yet hardly can believe,
About each Arm a Pudding-sleeve;
His Wastcoat to a Cassock grew,
And both assum'd a Sable Hue;
But being Old, continu'd just
As Thread-bare, and as full of Dust.
His Talk was now of  and ,
Cou'd smoak his Pipe, and read the News;
Knew how to preach old Sermons next,
Vampt in the Preface and the Text;
At Christnings well could act his Part,
And had the Service all by Heart;
Wish'd Women might have Children fast,
And thought whose  had  last:
Against  wou'd repine,
And stood up firm for :
Found his Head fill'd with many a System,
But Classick Authors â€” he ne'er miss'd e'em.
THUS having furbish'd up a Parson,
Dame  next they play'd their Farce on:
Instead of Home-spun Coifs were seen,
Good Pinners edg'd with Colberteen:
Her Petticoat transform'd apace,
Became Black Sattin, Flounc'd with Lace,
Plain  would no longer down,
'Twas , in her Grogram Gown.
was in great Surprize,
And hardly could believe his Eyes,
Amaz'd to see Her look so Prim,
And she admir'd as much at Him.

stanzas.stanza_text:
THUS having furbish'd up a Parson,
Dame  next they play'd their Farce on:
Instead of Home-spun Coifs were seen,
Good Pinners edg'd with Colberteen:
Her Petticoat transform'd apace,
Became Black Sattin, Flounc'd with Lace,
Plain  would no longer down,
'Twas , in her Grogram Gown.
was in great Surprize,
And hardly could believe his Eyes,
Amaz'd to see Her look so Prim,
And she admir'd as much at Him.

lines.line_text: THUS, happy in their Change of Life,
Were serveral Years this Man and Wife,
When on a Day, which prov'd their last,
Discoursing on old Stories past,
They went by chance, amidst their Talk,
To the Church-yard, to take a walk;
When  hastily cry'd out;
My Dear, I see your Forehead sprout:
Sprout, quoth the Man, What's this you tell us?
I hope you don't believe me Jealous:
But yet, methinks, I feel it ture;
And re'ly, Yours is budding too â€”
Nay, â€” now I cannot stir my Foot:
It feels as if 'twere taking Root.

stanzas.stanza_text:
THUS, happy in their Change of Life,
Were serveral Years this Man and Wife,
When on a Day, which prov'd their last,
Discoursing on old Stories past,
They went by chance, amidst their Talk,
To the Church-yard, to take a walk;
When  hastily cry'd out;
My Dear, I see your Forehead sprout:
Sprout, quoth the Man, What's this you tell us?
I hope you don't believe me Jealous:
But yet, methinks, I feel it ture;
And re'ly, Yours is budding too â€”
Nay, â€” now I cannot stir my Foot:
It feels as if 'twere taking Root.

lines.line_text: DESCRIPTION would but tire my Muse:
In short, they both were turn'd to .
Old Good-man  of the Green
Remembers he the Trees has seen;
He'll talk of them from Noon till Night,
And goes with Folks to shew the Sight:
On , after Ev'ning Prayer,
He gathers all the Parish there;
Points out the Place of either ;
Here , there  grew.
Till once, a Parson of our Town,
To mend his Barn, cut  down;
At which, 'tis hard to be believ'd,
How much the other Tree was griev'd,
Grew Scrubby, dy'd a-top, was stunted:
So, the next Parson stub'd and burnt it.

So, the next Parson stub'd and burnt it.
